data.body:
- VSCode 1.13.0:
- OS Version: Debian Stretch 
Linux yggdrasil 4.9.0-3-amd64 #1 SMP Debian 4.9.30-1 (2017-06-04) x86_64 GNU/Linux
Extensions
 - C/C++ 0.11.4
 - Code Runner 0.6.18
 - go 0.6.62
 - Instant Markdown 1.1.0
 - markdownlint 0.9.1
 - Python 0.6.4
 - Rust 0.3.14


Steps to Reproduce:

1.Open code with no files.
2. Enter the following code and save as "hello.c"
#include <stdio.h>

int main(int argc, const char** argv)
'''
{
    printf("Hello world\n");
}
'''

data.title: Terminal - Bash for windows when using and then exiting top command background in terminal is blue
data.body:
![vscodeissue](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/22580656/26999286-7feec60c-4d5b-11e7-99fe-755568217586.PNG)
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.14393
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|cpptools|ms-vscode|0.11.4|
|csharp|ms-vscode|1.10.0|
|PowerShell|ms-vscode|1.3.1|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.2|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. ```ctrl-~``` to open terminal. Type in ```bash``` at the command prompt to start using bash for windows.
2. type the ```top``` command. Terminal section will turn blue.
3. ```ctrl-c``` to stop using top. Returns to the bash shell. Background is blue.

Only way to clear the blue background color off is to kill the terminal session. Pressing ```ctrl-~``` to close then re-open does not fix the background color issue.

Expectation:
When top is exited out of then the background color of the terminal should return to the same color of the selected theme.

data.title: Output what C++ compile command is executed on the output view.
data.body:
I use tasks.json to build c++ code. Sometimes I want see the raw compile command when I share it to someone who does not use vscode. Is it possible to see what compile command is executed? 

e.g. 

tasks.json

```
{
    "version": "0.1.0",
    "command": "g++",
    "isShellCommand": true,
    "showOutput": "always",
    "args": ["-std=c++11", "-g", "main.cpp"]
}
```

Output:

```
g++ -std=c++11 -g main.cpp
```

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Mac OSX 10.11.6

data.title: NodeJS debugging won't stop on breakpoints, works fine with debugger
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0 and Insider and 1.12.2
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Attach debugger to node v4.4.6
2. Set breakpoint in code
3. Attempt to trigger breakpoint



Launch.json
```
        {
            "type": "node",
            "request": "attach",
            "name": "Server",
            "port": 5858,
            "processId": "${command:PickProcess}",
            "sourceMaps": true,
            "smartStep": true,
            "trace": true,
            "protocol": "legacy",
            "restart": true,
            "outFiles": [
                "${workspaceRoot}/build/**/*.js"
            ],
            "skipFiles": [
                "${workspaceRoot}/node_modules/**/*.js",
                "<node_internals>/**/*.js",
                "${workspaceRoot}build/meteor/**/*.js"
            ]
        },
```

Relevant parts of verbose debug console output
```
13404: _attach: address: 127.0.0.1 port: 5858
13404: _attach: connected
13404: __initialize: got process id 16304 from node
13404: _initialize: target node version: v4.4.6
13404: _injectDebuggerExtensions: code injection successful
13404: _startInitialize: stopped: true
```

```
13404: _registerSourceMap: e:/dev/arpeegee/src/universal/collections/task.ts -> e:/dev/arpeegee/build/server.js
```
Followed later when I set the breakpoint by this
```
13404: setBreakPointsRequest: {"path":"e:\\dev\\arpeegee\\src\\universal\\collections\\task.ts","name":"task.ts"} [{"line":903}]
13404: _mapSourceAndUpdateBreakpoints: src: 'e:\dev\arpeegee\src\universal\collections\task.ts' 902:0 -> gen: 'e:\Dev\arpeegee\build\server.js' 3114:0
13404: _setBreakpoint: {"type":"scriptRegExp","target":"^(.*[\\/\\\\])?[eE]:\\\\Dev\\\\arpeegee\\\\build\\\\server\\.js$","line":3114,"column":0}
13404: _updateBreakpoints: result [{"verified":true,"line":903,"column":1}]
```
It is picking up my source maps and appears to register the breakpoint correctly, it just never stops on it.

No output when I attempt to trigger the breakpoint. If I use ```debugger``` everything works perfectly with full source maps.

data.title: Implement selection inverting in the terminal again (or add terminal selection theme key)
data.body:
The new selection implementation removed the selection inverting feature from the terminal https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/pull/28388

We should either add it back (https://github.com/sourcelair/xterm.js/issues/692) or add a terminal selection background theme key.

data.title: Update parameter hint setting desc
data.body: Updating parameter hint setting description based on @radix suggestion: https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/28380#issuecomment-307517401

data.title: Add an API for showing Wizards and Dialog Boxes
data.body:
Currently, in order to get any information from the user, an extension has the following options:
* `showInputBox()`
* `showQuickPick()`

Both of those methods allow getting a single piece of information. (as opposed to a form containing multiple fields for the user to fill in)

While this is particularly efficient for getting simple data. (e.g. a "Rename" command might use `showInputBox()` to get the new name of a variable) it is (IMHO) rather inconvenient for getting more complex information.

For instance, if an extension wants to show a "wizard" that creates a new project in the currently open directory, an intuitive way would be to show a "window" that allows the user to fill in such parameters as:
1. Project name
1. The version of the language/standard to use
1. Project template
1. etc.

Since, VSCode doesn't provide an API for showing custom windows, the only way for getting these information would be to show consecutive input boxes. (using `showInputBox()`)
This means:
1. The user has to remember what they have entered
1. If the user remembers making a mistake in a previously validated input box, they have to cancel and start over

A concrete example of such behavior can be seen in the [yo](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=samverschueren.yo) extension.

Having all the fields displayed simultaneously would allow the user to:
1. Write AND correct themselves without having to start all over each time they make a mistake
1. Have a recap of all the information that has been entered and make changes if needed

Some extensions (e.g. [CMake Tools](https://marketplace.visualstudio.com/items?itemName=vector-of-bool.cmake-tools)) are working around this limitation by:
1. Showing an HTML page that contains input fields, buttons, etc. (implementing `TextDocumentContentProvider`)
1. Getting the information back using an HTTP server and WebSockets
1. (Perhaps, I haven't checked, but seems doable) Updating the content of the HTML page if needed

Clever!
I think, however, that it would be better if VSCode provided some API for showing simple, custom windows that would (at least) allow getting multiple data at once.

Some ideas:
* `showForm([{fieldName: "name", fieldType: "type"}...], okCallback, cancelCallback)`
* `showDialog(message, okCallback)`
* `showFancyWindow(be, creative)`

data.title: Settings tab doesn't preserve which items are expanded when switching tabs
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.10586
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|vscode-great-icons|emmanuelbeziat|2.1.7|
|php-debug|felixfbecker|1.10.0|
|php-intellisense|felixfbecker|1.3.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Open `settings.json` (File > Preferences > Settings)
2. Click on any item to expand it
3. Switch to another tab and back

The scroll will be at the correct position, but the first item will be expanded (Commonly Used) and the one you expanded will be collapsed.

data.title: 'Trigger Parameter Hints' Does not Work when `editor.parameterHints` is disabled
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.14 insiders
- OS Version: Mac 10.12

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Set `"editor.parameterHints": false`
1. In a js file, write: `setTimeout(|)` where `|` is the cursor position
2. Try to manually tigger parameter hints using the keyboard shortcut or the `Trigger Parameter hints` command 

**Expected**
Even though they are disabled, you should be able to manually trigger parameter hints using this command. This matches the behavior of our suggestions

**Actual**
Nothing happens when running the command

data.title: Tab selection with keyboard shortcuts
data.body:
The [keybindings doc](https://code.visualstudio.com/docs/getstarted/keybindings) shows two default keybindings for opening the NEXT tab and the Previous tab (Control + Tab and Control + Shift + Tab, respectively). One would expect this functionality to mimic Chrome and other browsers, but it does not. 

When Control + Tab is hit multiple times (releasing both keys completely between iterations), the result is a toggle between the current tab and next tab.

To clarify further: if we focus on the items in the dropdown that appears, both keybindings do exactly what they're supposed to do; they cycle through the open files forward or backward when the Control key is held down and we tap on the Tab key. However, if we release both keys after every attempt to advance to the next tab, the functionality breaks.

I get this result even when I start Code with the `--disable-extensions` flag.

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: MacOS Sierra (10.12.5)

data.title: Iteration Plan for June 2017
data.body:
This plan captures our work in June. This is a **4 week** iteration. We will ship **early July**. The main focus of this iteration is to continue pushing on the big rock item #396 "Multi-folder workspaces".

## Endgame
- *June 26th*: Code freeze for the endgame
- *June 30th*: Endgame done

The endgame details for this iteration are tracked in #29518

## Plan Items

Below is a summary of the top level plan items.

Legend of annotations:

| Mark | Description |
| ------------- | ------------- |
| :runner: | work in progress  |
| :hand: | blocked task |
| :muscle: | stretch goal for this iteration  |
| :large_blue_circle: | more details required |
| :red_circle: | missing issue reference |


### Workbench
- [x] :runner: Multi-folder workspaces #28344 (feature request #396) @bpasero @tyriar **@ team**
- [x] Improve window switching #25145 @bpasero
- [x] Finish emmet 2.0 support #27697 @ramya-rao-a
- [x] Finish Tasks v2.0 improvements #28235 @dbaeumer 

### Editor
- [x] Improve indentation of lines #28658 @rebornix

### Monaco Editor
- [x] New release of the Monaco Editor Microsoft/monaco-editor#467 [milestone](https://github.com/Microsoft/monaco-editor/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+milestone%3Av0.9.x) @alexandrudima

### Accessibility
- [x] :runner: Improve accessibility of the Monaco editor [See query.](https://github.com/Microsoft/monaco-editor/issues?q=is%3Aopen+is%3Aissue+label%3Aaccessibility) @alexandrudima
- [x] :muscle: Improve accessibility of the diff editor #17263 @alexandrudima
- [x] Improve accessibility of the Tree/List widget #27900 @isidorn

### Debug
- [x] Autodetect debug protocol for SIGUSR1 initiated debugging #25036 @roblourens @weinand
- [x] Translation support for inspector protocol based debug adapters Microsoft/vscode-node-debug2#83 @roblourens

### Install/update
- [x] Provide Windows 64-bit install for the Insiders build #507 @joaomoreno
- [x] Make update notification less invasive on Mac (promote from insiders to stable) @joaomoreno @isidorn

### Integrated Terminal
- [x] Support selecting and copy more than just the visible text in a terminal #9958 @tyriar 
- [x] Support find in the terminal output #15198 @Tyriar @rebornix 

### Languages

##### JavaScript/TypeScript
 - [x] Bundle [TypeScript 2.4](https://github.com/Microsoft/TypeScript/wiki/Roadmap#24) #28056 @mjbvz
 - [x] Support TS 2.4 refactorings #25739 @mjbvz

### Extensions

##### API
- [x] Finish Task Provider API #27575, #27577, #27582, #27587 @dbaeumer
- [x] Debug: support a `debug session terminated` event #28234 @weinand
- [x] Custom sections: support conditional visibility based on a context (when clause) #29436 @sandy081

##### Extension management
- [x] Add sections for installed and recommended sections to the extensions viewlet #28663 @sandy081

### Extension Contributions
- [x] Go https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode-go/issues/959 @ramya-rao-a
- [x] Polish PHP language server https://github.com/felixfbecker/php-language-server/issues/404 @roblourens
- [x] :runner: Polish Git extension #28657 @rebornix
- [x] Polish Github extension #28631 @chrmarti

### Engineering items
- [x] Investigate using snapshots for `workbench.main.js` to speed up startup #28492 @jrieken
- [x] Build definition for smoke test #27845 @michelkaporin
- [x] Smoke test build status indicator #28586 @michelkaporin
- [x] :runner: Improve issue tracking with automation #26223 @chrmarti

### Documentation
- [x] Add recipe for Angular debugging weinand/vscode-recipes#1 @weinand

----

### Deferred
- Enable electron crash reporter for all processes #21944 @ramya-rao-a
- Allow users to manage custom sections in the explorer #27823 @sandy081
- `DocumentContentProvider` support to update document content #10547 @jrieken
- Implement extension host debugging for inspector protocol Microsoft/vscode-node-debug2#4 @weinand @bpasero @roblourens
- Improve update experience on Windows #26199 @joaomoreno, @isidorn
- :runner: Show loaded scripts in a custom explorer section #28521 @weinand
- Avoid process leakage of the extension host #15962 @alexandrudima
- Investigate language packs for translations #29008 @dbaumer
---
- Support custom sections in other viewlets #28662 @sandy081 
- Provide out-of-the-box color picker #28587 @michelkaporin
- Adopt TS 2.4 #28643 @mjbvz
- Adopt Electron `1.7.2` #28582 @bpasero

data.title: Better experience with bower and other package managers
data.body:
<!-- Do you have a question? Please ask it on http://stackoverflow.com/questions/tagged/vscode -->

- VSCode Version: 1.13
- OS Version: Windows 10 64bit

In may release vscode ships with highlevel  tasks support for gulp , grunt, npm-scripts.
But frontend developers also use some tools like bower.
I am understand what bower and other package managers arent a task toosl, but it will be great for vscode to  work with them  on higher level then current. That might be a lot of features which can be implemented.
For example it might be such thinks like a: detecting list of depencies from current project or current package json, options to install all or some of dependencies from this list, detecting the deprecated packages, update all of dependecies or only some of them and etc, search in global bower register and install depencies from it , etc.

I know what some plugins with same features maybe already exist, but making such tools integrated into core , with more options and features, will make vscode only better and more proffesional tool , with better user experience.

Thanks to the team for such good editor, i am hopefully wait for your mind's about this. Thank you!

data.title: [Javascript] Go to definition not working
data.body:
Go to definition, hover, and other intellisense feature does't work on methods and properties that were dynamically assigned to an object.

- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Windows 10

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create and object 
`var myObj = { 
foo: function(){console.log('foo')}
}`
2. Dynamically assign a method to the object
`myObj.bar = function(){console.log('bar')}`
3. Call method bar
`myObj.bar()`
4. Try go to definition on the call to method bar

data.title: command 'workbench.view.git' not found on keyboard shortcut execution
data.body:
- VSCode Version: **1.13.0**
- OS Version: **MacOS Version 10.12.2**

### Steps to Reproduce

1. Set `workbench.view.git` user keybinding (I did CTRL + shift + G)
2. Execute the keyboard shortcut
3. The warning "command 'workbench.view.git' not found" is shown

### Notes

1. Actually clicking the Git icon in the  #Activity Bar still pulls up the Git panel and stages/commits/pushes can still be made; the issue is just getting to it with the keyboard shortcut.
2. There are no errors/warnings related to this in the Dev Tools Console

data.title: Markdown syntax hylighting for pug and sass/scss?
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|jshint|dbaeumer|0.10.15|
|vscode-todo-parser|minhthai|1.8.10|
|debugger-for-chrome|msjsdiag|3.1.2|
|language-liquid|neilding|0.0.2|
|vscode-jest|Orta|2.2.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Create markdown file something like:
````markdown
# Sass?
The following would work if I used `css` but does not work for `sass` or `scss`: 
```scss
$background: black;

body {
    background: $background;
}
```
# Pug?
The following would work if I used `jade` but does not work for `pug`: 
```pug
h1 Hello world!
```
````

Pug is the new name for Jade so it would be cool if the syntax highlighting inside markdown files would work for `pug` as well. Sass support will probably be trickier. Do you guys use a third-party tool for syntax highlighting inside markdown? I would be happy to look into a pull request for these. Just not sure where to start.

data.title: Editor keys don't work correctly on Ubuntu LXDE desktop
data.body:
- VSCode Version: 1.13.0
- OS Version: Ubuntu 16.04.2

- Desktop: LXDE (also known as lubuntu)
- Remote Access: tightvncserver

Steps to Reproduce:

1. In the code editor, type the number 5 in the row above the letters, you get a backspace (regardless of shift key)
2. Type 6, you get a tab
3. The number keys on the right side of the keyboard don't work at all

I am running on an EC2 instance in AWS. Desktop and remote access methods as noted above. To start with, VS Code won't even run unless you make the change noted in [issue 3451](https://github.com/Microsoft/vscode/issues/3451).

The keyboard problems don't happen when typing in the terminal window, the find dialog, etc. It only happens in the editor.

data.title: Can't figure out how to disable documentation popup when typing TypeScript code
data.body:
- VSCode Version: Code 1.13.0 (376c52b955428d205459bea6619fc161fc8faacf, 2017-06-08T16:43:13.058Z)
- OS Version: Windows_NT ia32 10.0.15063
- Extensions: 

|Extension|Author|Version|
|---|---|---|
|python|donjayamanne|0.6.4|
|tslint|eg2|0.15.0|
|vscode-rust|kalitaalexey|0.3.14|
|wordcount|ms-vscode|0.1.0|
|elm|sbrink|0.13.0|
|vscode-lldb|vadimcn|0.5.0|;


---

Steps to Reproduce:

1. Type some typescript code
2. See documentation popups, which cover up code I'm trying to look at while writing, and some of which take over my up and down arrow keys (when there is more than one type signature for a function that I'm calling).

I'd like to disable these documentation popups (ideally, I could have a keyboard shortcut to make them appear when I need them). I've searched my user settings for various keywords, like "popup", "doc", "typescript" and so on, but I haven't found it. Is it possible to disable them? If there is, then it probably needs to be made more discoverable.

Note that I have already successfully disabled all automatic suggestions; this is only happening for documentation now.
